cards.front: What is the circuit theory definition of a two-terminal resistor?
cards.back: Any two-terminal element whose voltage v and current i satisfy a relationship f(v, i) = 0.

cards.front: Write the set notation for the v-i characteristic of a resistor.
cards.back: R = {(v, i) : f(v, i) = 0} — the set of all (v, i) pairs that satisfy the device's voltage-current relationship.

cards.front: How does the circuit theory definition of 'resistor' differ from the physics definition?
cards.back: Physics: a resistor obeys Ohm's law (v = Ri). Circuit theory: a resistor is any two-terminal element with any v-i relationship, including nonlinear devices, diodes, and sources.

cards.front: On the v-i plane, which variable is the horizontal axis?
cards.back: Voltage (v) is the horizontal axis (abscissa), and current (i) is the vertical axis (ordinate). The first variable in 'v-i' is always the horizontal.

cards.front: Is a DC voltage source a 'resistor' in circuit theory? Why?
cards.back: Yes. A DC voltage source has the characteristic v = Vs for all i, which satisfies f(v, i) = v - Vs = 0. It is a two-terminal element with a defined v-i relationship.

cards.front: What is the difference between a time-invariant and a time-varying resistor?
cards.back: Time-invariant: v-i relationship does not change with time (e.g., v = Ri, R constant). Time-varying: v-i relationship changes with time (e.g., v(t) = R(t) i(t) where R changes).

cards.front: Why is the v-i characteristic called the 'fundamental description' of a two-terminal resistor?
cards.back: Because it completely specifies the device's electrical behaviour — if you know all (v, i) pairs that satisfy f(v, i) = 0, you know everything about how the device will behave in any circuit.

cards.front: Give three examples of devices that are 'resistors' in circuit theory but not in the physics sense.
cards.back: Ideal diode, PN-junction diode, DC voltage source, DC current source, tunnel diode, open circuit, short circuit — all have two terminals and a v-i relationship.
The device has exactly two connection points (terminals) — one where current enters and one where current leaves. Examples: resistor leads, diode anode/cathode, battery +/-.

cards.front: What is the practical advantage of the broad circuit theory definition of 'resistor'?
cards.back: All analysis techniques (series/parallel rules, graphical analysis, load-line method, PWL approximation) work for any two-terminal resistor, not just linear ones. One set of tools covers all devices.
